rounds.response:
Alright, let me think through what to do next. Right now my total value is:

- Wheat: 6 × 5 = 30  
- Wood: 22 × 12 = 264  
- Sheep: 12 × 15 = 180  
- Brick: 23 × 25 = 575  
- Ore: 5 × 35 = 175  
Total = 30 + 264 + 180 + 575 + 175 = 1,224  

I notice I have a *lot* of brick (23) and my lowest-valued resource is wheat (only 5 value per unit). Meanwhile, ore is my most valuable per unit (35 value each), and I have very few (5). 

Player 0 didn’t offer anything this turn, which usually signals either they’re waiting or they’re uncertain about what to propose. I should take the lead by offering something tempting that clearly benefits me, while remaining fair enough that they might bite.

I’m willing to give up some brick (which I have in surplus) and perhaps wheat (low value) in exchange for ore. Here’s one idea:

[Offer: 4 Brick, 4 Wheat -> 3 Ore, 1 Sheep]

rounds.response:
Let me re-calculate how the last exchange would affect me.

Player 0’s most-recent offer  
 Give away: 1 Brick (worth **25**)  
 Receive: 4 Wheat (worth **5 × 4 = 20**)  

Net change for me = 20 – 25 = **–5 value**, so this is a bad deal.

Updated inventory (assuming no trades happened so far):
• Wheat: 6 (value 5)  
• Wood: 22 (value 12)  
• Sheep: 12 (value 15)  
• Brick: 23 (value 25)  
• Ore: 5  (value 35)  

Since the prior offer was rejected and the new one is unfavorable, I’ll propose a revised trade that gives me positively-valued Ore without over-paying.

[Offer: 5 Brick, 1 Sheep -> 2 Ore, 1 Wood]

rounds.response:
I'm reviewing what’s happened so far:

Turn-1: I tried to send 4 Brick plus 4 Wheat for 3 Ore + 1 Sheep.  
Value change for me would have been −25 for the outgoing Brick, −5 for the Wheat, and +105 for the Ore and +15 for the incoming Sheep → net gain of +90. That was clearly in my favour, so Player 0 naturally denied it.

Turn-2: Player 0 offered me 4 Wheat for 1 Brick.  
Value change for me would have been +5 for the Wheat, −25 for the Brick → net loss of 20. I denied.

Turn-3: I sent 5 Brick + 1 Sheep for 2 Ore + 1 Wood.  
Value change would be −125 + 15 for the sent goods, +70 + 12 for the acquired goods → net gain of −28. That deal was no good for me either; Player 0 denied, as expected.

Their pattern seems to be:
- Rejecting any deal that significantly helps me.
- Offering me Wheat at a poor exchange rate to soak up my Brick.

I still have 23 Brick, and Ore is by far the most valuable commodity to me (35 per unit). Meanwhile they appear to have a surplus of Wheat (they already offered me 4 Wheat for 1 Brick, so they must have ≥4 Wheat).

I’ll now propose a turn-4 offer that I believe will look enticing to them yet nets me the Ore I need without hurting my Brick stock too much.

[Offer: 1 Ore, 5 Sheep -> 3 Ore]

rounds.response:
[HOLD- Turn: 7]

I currently have:
- 22 Wood (12 pts) → waste beyond multiples-of-3 for longest road
- 23 Brick (25 pts) → very close to 24 needed for four cities
- 5 Ore (35 pts)   → already have enough for 3 cities, but only 2 ore left if I build them now
- 12 Sheep (15 pts) → more than enough; only need 4 Dev-card sheep temporarily
- 6 Wheat (5 pts) → the scarcest resource for me

Net marginal value per card at this point:
- ONE extra Wheat is worth +60 (for 3× Wheat to fill third city)
- Ore is only worth +35 if I get ≥ one more, because I lose a city-token each time I spend it
- Brick beyond 24/27 is worth 0 beyond VP value
- Wood beyond 20 is worth 0 beyond VP value
- Sheep beyond 4-5 is mostly worth 0

THEREFORE Maximising-Turn 7-10 plan: convert my surplus Brick/Sheep/Wood into Ore then into Wheat so I can empty Wheat hand.

I will first probe how highly Player 0 values Wheat.

[Offer: 5 Brick, 1 Sheep -> 3 Wheat]

This keeps Ore intact and tests whether they want to offload Wheat.

rounds.response:
Status after the completed talks:
- Turns used so far: 2 rejected (my own) offers + 2 rejected (their) offers + 4 rejected further offers  ➜ still only two full turns have elapsed.

Current stock
Wheat 6→30
Wood 22→12           Total = 803
Sheep 12→15  =180
Brick 23→25  =575
Ore   5→35   =175
Grand total value = 803

Key insight
– Brick is plentiful (23) but Brick→Ore ≤ 0.71 value per unit and Brick→Wood ≤ 0.52.
– Ore is scarce (5) and the most valuable good (7 value per unit more than Brick and 23 value per unit more than any other good).
– I am willing to trade Brick only for Ore and will pay a generous rate to obtain it.

Straight-to-the-point next offer
[Offer: 5 Brick -> 1 Ore]
